ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In-depth understanding of the Prehistory of Africa, spanning the Miocene to the recent. Great overview. Also critical thinking and analytical skills, in addition to research and writing.

I learned a lot of archaeological practices and methods of observation, how to correlate multiple types of evidence to make inferences about unclear archaeological artifacts and speculate on their use or meaning, as well as a more complete knowledge of how humans evolved and how that came about.

A fascinating survey of African Prehistory and what the current knowledge is of human origins. You learn about preservation, archaeological reports, and the development of the human species through an intersection of several different hominin species originating in Africa. You also learn about societies and cultures of Africa, the rise of cities and the Neolithic revolution, and the specific work of the professors in the field.

As an absolute beginner to archaeology, I learned about what archaeologists actually do and what tools/methods they use, and what factors (environmental, social, political) affect their finds findings. I also learned about the evolution of hominids, and the beginnings of modern human behavior.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The midterm was extremely intense, while the final was chill. Undecided if that's a strength or weakness. 

Great job of covering so much material in a comprehensive manner.

I prefer lectures to take place in the class, and virtual lectures can be a bit dry and hard to focus on. Not being able to ask questions in the moment can be frustrating. 
The class had issues where data on the syllabus was changed abruptly without modification to the syllabus itself or a visible announcement. This will be discussed more.
The class did not discuss the readings often. It would have been nice to have a discussion section or devote some of class time to going through some very interesting readings that felt like an afterthought.
I think it could be improved by inspiring more discussion, and also by giving reminders about the weekly section reports.

Strengths: The subjects taught are super interesting, and the professors are great! Weaknesses: As an absolute beginner, the readings were tough for me to follow. The good thing was that all of the readings didn't end up being super critical -- there were just certain ones that I reread for the regional comparison assignment.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lecture format followed by a period of questions, which really worked for me.

The lectures were good, but I was a little disappointed that I never got the opportunity to really talk with the other students in the class! Since we couldn't talk to each other while walking to class and we never got put in breakout rooms, I really went the entire semester without interacting very much with the other students.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, definitely for anyone who wants to know more about African archaeology or the history of archaeology or human evolution and how it is situated in Africa.

The class is fascinating and I found it a good primer for students wanting to get into archaeology. The professors are knowledgeable and experts in their fields and answered questions gracefully and effectively, even if there was often not enough time for them. I would recommend it, but recommend students pay very close attention to the dates and information regarding assessments to ensure they do not suffer in the same way our class did.
Yes! Especially if you are interested in the origins of humanity, and the rise of human culture in Africa.

Yes! It was a great course as someone who has no experience in archaeology and didn't really like history in high school. You learn a lot and it's very fun, as long as you're willing to put in the work. A word of advice -- start the regional comparison several weeks early!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
